FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these rules which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism (methamphetamines). Provisions have been made to install protective barriers around the perimeter of the plant and its appurtenances to reduce the potential for vehicular damage.
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Flow Limiters=what in the trade is called an excess flow valve. Breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remote emergency shut-off valve installed at the storage tank.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspection/Routine preventive maintenance & repairs
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: VALVES, PIPING, TANKS, HOSES, RELIEF VALVES, EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN, HYDROSTATIC VALVES

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Ag Max Partners
107 5th Ave. N.W.
Britt, IA  50423

For further information contact Ron Schachtner, operations manager - Phone 641-444-4004

Risk Management Plant - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.  The Facility Plan

            The owners, management and employees of Ag Max Partners are committed to the prevention of any accidential releases of anydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire company, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  Facility Information

            The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers.          

            Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application.  Anhydrous ammonia  is used for crop production nutirents.

             The maximum quantity of ammonia stored would be 411,000 lbs in our 94,000 gallon storage tank(s) and nurse tanks.  The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a tank truck holding 40,000 pounds.

3.  The worst case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.

             a.  The worst case release scenario for anhydrous ammonia would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank (18,000-gallon capacity) released as a gas liquified by pressure over ten minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 78,750 pounds which represents the volume of the storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 3.3 miles.

             b.  The alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia based on the hazard review is a 10 minute release from a break in a 4- inch pipe.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 0.1 miles.

4.  The accidential release prevention program.

               The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling

of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published  by the American National Standards Institute, Inc.  and the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia".  In addition, Iowa Department of Ag Rules.

5.  The Five-year Accident History

       a.  There have been no accidential releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
                have caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our 
                knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property
                damage or environmental damage.

6.  The Emergency Response Program.

            The facility has (is):

a.  Included in the Wright County, Iowa written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

b.  Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

c.  Coordinated with local emergency responders.

7.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

           Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
